content.title: Introduction
content.sortContent:
What is HTML?
HTML is a markup language for describing web documents (web pages).

content.title: Editors
content.sortContent:
HTML can be edited by using professional HTML editors like:
  • Microsoft WebMatrix
  • Sublime Text

content.title: Basic
content.sortContent:
All HTML documents must start with a type declaration: <!DOCTYPE html>.
The HTML document itself begins with <html> and ends with </html>.
The visible part of the HTML document is between <body> and </body>.

content.title: Elements
content.sortContent:
HTML documents are made up by HTML elements.
HTML elements are written with a start tag, with an end tag, with the content in between:
<tagname> content </tagname>

content.title: Attributes
content.sortContent:
• HTML elements can have attributes
  • Attributes provide additional information about an element
  • Attributes are always specified in the start tag
  • Attributes come in name/value pairs like: name='value'

content.title: Headings
content.sortContent:
Headings are important in HTML documents.
Headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags.
<h1> defines the most important heading. <h6> defines the least important heading.

content.title: Paragraphs
content.sortContent:
The HTML <p> element defines a paragraph.

This is a paragraph

This is another paragraph

content.title: Styles
content.sortContent:
Every HTML element has a default style (background color is white and text color is black).
Changing the default style of an HTML element, can be done with the style attribute.

content.title: Formatting
content.sortContent:
HTML also defines special elements, for defining text with a special meaning.
HTML uses elements like <b> and <i> for formatting output, like bold or italic text.

content.title: Quotations
content.sortContent:
The HTML <q> element defines a short quotation. Browsers usually insert quotation marks around the <q> element.

WWF's goal is to: Build a future where people live in harmony with nature.

content.title: Computer Code
content.sortContent:
Normally, HTML uses variable letter size, and variable letter spacing.
This is not wanted when displaying examples of computer code.
The <kbd>, <samp>, and <code> elements all support fixed letter size and spacing.

content.title: Comments
content.sortContent:
You can add comments to your HTML source by using the following syntax:
<!-- Write your comments here -->

content.title: CSS
content.sortContent:
CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets
Styling can be added to HTML elements in 3 ways:
  • Inline - using a style attribute in HTML elements
  • Internal - using a <style> element in the HTML <head> section
  • External - using one or more external CSS files

content.title: Links
content.sortContent:
HTML links are hyperlinks.
A hyperlink is a text or an image you can click on, and jump to another document.
<a href='url '>link text</a>

content.title: Images
content.sortContent:
In HTML, images are defined with the <img> tag.
The <img> tag is empty, it contains attributes only, and does not have a closing tag.
The src attribute specifies the URL (web address) of the image:
<img src='url ' alt='some_text ' >

content.title: Tables
content.sortContent:
NumberFirst NameLast NamePoints
1EveJackson94

content.title: Lists
content.sortContent:
Unordered lists and ordered lists are commonly used in HTML:

Unordered List

  • The first item
  • The second item
  • The third item
  • The fourth item

Ordered List

  1. The first item
  2. The second item
  3. The third item
  4. The fourth item

content.title: Blocks
content.sortContent: Every HTML element has a default display value depending on what type of element it is. The default display value for most elements is block or inline.

content.title: Classes
content.sortContent:
The HTML class attribute makes it possible to define equal styles for 'equal' <div> elements.
The HTML class attribute also makes it possible to define equal styles for 'equal' <span> elements

content.title: Layout
content.sortContent: Websites often display content in multiple columns (like a magazine or newspaper). The <div> element is often used as a layout tool, because it can easily be positioned with CSS.

content.title: Responsive
content.sortContent:
What is Responsive Web Design?
  • RWD stands for Responsive Web Design
  • RWD can deliver web pages in variable sizes
  • RWD is a must for tablets and mobile devices

content.title: Iframes
content.sortContent:
An iframe is used to display a web page within a web page.
The syntax for adding an iframe is:
<iframe src='URL'></iframe>

The src attribute specifies the URL (web address) of the iframe page.

content.title: Color Names
content.sortContent: All modern browsers support the following 140 color names (click on a color name, or a hex value, to view the color as the background-color along with different text colors)

content.title: Color Values
content.sortContent:
Colors in HTML can be specified by the following methods:
  • Hexadecimal colors
  • RGB colors
  • Color names

content.title: Color Shades
content.sortContent:
Gray colors are displayed using an equal amount of power to all of the light sources.
To make it easy for you to select a gray color we have compiled a table of gray shades for you

content.title: Javascript
content.sortContent: JavaScripts make HTML pages more dynamic and interactive.

content.title: Head
content.sortContent:
The <head> element is a container for meta data (data about data).
HTML meta data is data about the HTML document. Metadata is not displayed.
Meta data typically define document title, styles, links, scripts, and other meta information.
The following tags describes meta data: <title>, <style>, <meta>, <link>, <script>, and <base>.

content.title: Entities
content.sortContent:
Reserved characters in HTML must be replaced with character entities.
Characters, not present on your keyboard, can also be replaced by entities.

content.title: Symbols
content.sortContent:
HTML entities were described in the previous chapter.
Many mathematical, technical, and currency symbols, are not present on a normal keyboard.
To add these symbols to an HTML page, you can use an HTML entity name.
If no entity name exists, you can use an entity number; a decimal (or hexadecimal) reference.

content.title: Charset
content.sortContent: To display an HTML page correctly, a web browser must know the character set (character encoding) to use.

content.title: URL Encode
content.sortContent:
A URL is another word for a web address.
A URL can be composed of words (w3schools.com), or an Internet Protocol (IP) address (192.68.20.50).
Most people enter the name when surfing, because names are easier to remember than numbers.

content.title: XHTML
content.sortContent:
XHTML is HTML written as XML.
  • XHTML stands for EXtensible HyperText Markup Language
  • XHTML is almost identical to HTML
  • XHTML is stricter than HTML
  • XHTML is HTML defined as an XML application
  • XHTML is supported by all major browsers

content.title: Forms
content.sortContent:
HTML forms are used to collect user input.
The <form> element defines an HTML form.
HTML forms contain form elements.
Form elements are different types of input elements, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, and more.

content.title: Form Elements
content.sortContent: This chapter describes all HTML form elements.

content.title: Input Types
content.sortContent: This chapter describes the input types of the <input> element.

content.title: Input Attributes
content.sortContent: This chapter describes the input attributes of the <input> element.
